channel.title: NPR Topics: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: What does normal look like in Caracas one month after the Maduro operation?
item.description: Nearly a month after U.S. forces seized Nicolás Maduro, Caracas is settling into an uneasy normal, with major changes and lingering questions about what lasts and what comes next.
item.content:encoded: Nearly a month after U.S. forces seized Nicolás Maduro, Caracas is settling into an uneasy normal, with major changes and lingering questions about what lasts and what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Manuel Rueda

item.title: Swiss Alpine bar fire claims 41st victim, an 18-year-old Swiss national
item.description: Swiss prosecutors have opened a criminal investigation into the owners of Le Constellation bar in the ski resort of Crans-Montana, where a fire in the early hours of Jan. 1 killed dozens.
item.content:encoded:
Swiss prosecutors have opened a criminal investigation into the owners of Le Constellation bar in the ski resort of Crans-Montana, where a fire in the early hours of Jan. 1 killed dozens.

(Image credit: Cyril Zingaro)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: At a clown school near Paris, failure is the lesson
item.description: For decades, students at the Ecole Philippe Gaulier have been paying to bomb onstage. The goal isn't laughs — it's learning how to take the humiliation and keep going.
item.content:encoded:
For decades, students at the Ecole Philippe Gaulier have been paying to bomb onstage. The goal isn't laughs — it's learning how to take the humiliation and keep going.

(Image credit: Rebecca Rosman for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Rosman

item.title: In the world's driest desert, Chile freezes its future to protect plants
item.description: Tucked away in a remote desert town, a hidden vault safeguards Chile's most precious natural treasures. From long-forgotten flowers to endangered crops.
item.content:encoded:
Tucked away in a remote desert town, a hidden vault safeguards Chile's most precious natural treasures. From long-forgotten flowers to endangered crops.

(Image credit: John Bartlett for NPR)
item.dc:creator: John Bartlett

item.title: Iran's supreme leader warns any US attack would spark 'regional war'
item.description: Iran's supreme leader warned Sunday that any attack by the United States would spark a "regional war" in the Mideast, further escalating tensions as President Donald Trump has threatened to militarily strike the Islamic Republic.
item.content:encoded:
Iran's supreme leader warned Sunday that any attack by the United States would spark a "regional war" in the Mideast, further escalating tensions as President Donald Trump has threatened to militarily strike the Islamic Republic.

(Image credit: Seaman Daniel Kimmelman)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Gaza border crossing buzzes with activity after years of near-complete closure
item.description: Reopening the border crossing is a key step as the Israel-Hamas ceasefire moves ahead.
item.content:encoded:
Reopening the border crossing is a key step as the Israel-Hamas ceasefire moves ahead.

(Image credit: Mohammed Arafat)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: U.S. intervention in Venezuela divides Houston
item.description: In nearly two dozen interviews, Houstonians expressed everything from admiration and relief to skepticism and dread following the seizure of leader Nicolás Maduro.
item.content:encoded:
In nearly two dozen interviews, Houstonians expressed everything from admiration and relief to skepticism and dread following the seizure of leader Nicolás Maduro.

(Image credit: Danielle Villasana for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Frank Langfitt

item.title: Mine collapses in eastern Congo, leaving at least 200 dead
item.description: The collapse happened Wednesday due to heavy rains at the rebel-controlled Rubaya mines. Congo is a major supplier of coltan, which contains a key component in the production of smartphones.
item.content:encoded:
The collapse happened Wednesday due to heavy rains at the rebel-controlled Rubaya mines. Congo is a major supplier of coltan, which contains a key component in the production of smartphones.

(Image credit: Moses Sawasawa)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: On a trip to Denmark, a reporter sees lawmakers take on the role of diplomats
item.description: NPR congressional correspondent Barbara Sprunt watched U.S. lawmakers attempt a diplomatic rescue mission in Denmark amid the Greenland crisis.
item.content:encoded: NPR congressional correspondent Barbara Sprunt watched U.S. lawmakers attempt a diplomatic rescue mission in Denmark amid the Greenland crisis.
item.dc:creator: Linah Mohammad

item.title: After backsliding, democracy often comes back weaker and more fragile
item.description: Losing democracy once can make it harder to restore it, even after a democratic government returns to power. University of Birmingham professor Nic Cheeseman analyzed three decades of data.
item.content:encoded: Losing democracy once can make it harder to restore it, even after a democratic government returns to power. University of Birmingham professor Nic Cheeseman analyzed three decades of data.
item.dc:creator: Ahmad Damen
